com.thesonofthom.tools

Class BufferMap

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.thesonofthom.tools.Buffer
      • com.thesonofthom.tools.BufferMap
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    BmpHeaderMap, BmpHeaderMap.BitfieldMask, BmpHeaderMap.BitmapFileHeader, BmpHeaderMap.CieXYZ, BmpHeaderMap.CieXYZTriple, BmpHeaderMap.DIBHeader, BmpHeaderMap.RGBQuad, PngFileMap, PngFileMap.Chunk, PngFileMap.ChunkData, PngFileMap.IHDRChunk, PngFileMap.PLTEChunkData.PLTEChunkEntry, PngFileMap.PngHeader, WinExeFileHeaderMap, WinExeFileHeaderMap.DOSHeaderMap, WinExeFileHeaderMap.PEHeaderMap, WinExeFileHeaderMap.PEHeaderMap.COFFHeaderMap, WinExeFileHeaderMap.PEHeaderMap.COFFHeaderMap.COFFHeaderCharacteristics, WinExeFileHeaderMap.PEHeaderMap.DataDirectory, WinExeFileHeaderMap.PEHeaderMap.DLLCharacteristics, WinExeFileHeaderMap.PEHeaderMap.PEOptionalHeader

    public class BufferMap
extends Buffer
    This class is a powerful tool that can be used to easily parse a binary buffer of data (byte array) that contains static, known data. Once the structure of the buffer is defined, the class can automatically generate a human-readable dump of the entire buffer without requiring the user to have to write their own toString() method, while simultaneously giving the user easy access to each field that was defined in the structure.

    The purpose of this class is to eliminate the need to write separate get() and set() methods for each field that needs to be parsed, as well as needing to manually iterate over each field and printing it in a human readable, aligned format when implementing the toString() method.

    This class works best when the fields in the buffer being parsed are statically defined, but it can also work with dynamic data with some extra effort.

    It generally also works best on small files. Since an object is created for every single field in the buffer that is being parsed, the memory usage of this class can grow significantly

    When defining the structure of the buffer, each field is represented by an Object. These can be one of the following types:

    • NumberField - for basic numbers ranging from 1 to 8 bytes in size
    • EnumNumberField - a NumberField that can optionally also evaluate to an Enum
    • StaticNumberField - a NumberField that must contain the specified expected value or an IllegalValueInStaticFieldException is thrown when the BufferMap is constructed
    • StringField - for data that can be evaluated as an ASCII string. No constraints on size
    • StaticStringField - a StringField that must contain the specified expected value or an IllegalValueInStaticFieldException is thrown when the BufferMap is constructed
    • NullTerminatedStringField - a StringField for strings of an unknown size that terminate in the NULL character \0
    • BitField - for data that is 1 bit in length
    • BitsField - for data that is from 2 to 8 bits in length (the data MUST reside within a single byte)
    • EnumBitsField - like EnumNumberField, but for values less than a byte in size
    • BufferField- for a large amount of data that does not need to be parsed. User can control whether or not to print the data when toString() is called
    • NumberArrayField - for an array of numbers. The values in the array can each be from 1 to 8 bytes in size
    Advanced Fields:
    • ComplexField<E extends BufferMap> - if the buffer contains a substructure that you wish to define as a single unit, that unit can be defined in it's own BufferMap that can be wrapped by this field
    • ComplexArrayField<E extends BufferMap> - used to designate when the buffer contains an array of a complex structure.
      • Each element int the array is described by ComplexField
    • ReservedField - for data that does not need to be parsed.
    • ReservedBitsField - for data that is not on a byte boundary that does not need to be parsed

    For each field needing to be defined, declare an object of the relevant class with the name you wish to see printed in the toString() along with the size of the field. The offset of the field into the buffer is not specified, as it is calculated from the sizes of the previously defined fields. Note that when defining the list of fields, only the size of the field is defined. The offset of the field is automatically calculated based on the order of the field in the map. All bytes and bits in the map must be accounted for. Since offset is not specified, no bytes can be skipped when declaring each field. For data that does not need to be parsed, use ReservedField or ReservedBitsField.

    For example: 

     public ExampleBufferMap extends BufferMap
 {
      public ExampleBufferMap(byte[] b)
      {
          super("Example", b, Endian.LITTLE);
      }
    
      public NumberField FirstField = new NumberField("First Field Name", 1); //byte 0
 
      //a NumberField does not have to be aligned to the standard single byte, short (2 bytes), int (4 bytes), or long (8 bytes)
      public NumberField SecondField = new NumberField("Second Field Name", 3); //bytes 1-3
 
      public StringField ThirdField = new StringField("Third Field Name", 14); //bytes 4 - 17
 
      //when declaring bits field within a single byte, every single bit must be accounted for before moving on to the next byte
      public BitField FourthFieldBit0 = new BitField("Fourth Field, Bit 0 Name"); // byte 18, bit 0
      public BitsField FourthFieldBit1_5 = new BitsField("Fourth Field, Bits 1-5 Name", 5); //byte 18, bits 1-5
      
      //reserved bits fields can span across multiple bytes.
      public ReservedBitsField Reserved = new ReservedBitsField(10); //byte 18, bits 6-7, all of byte 19 (bits 0 - 7)
 
      //when toString() is printed, the data within this complex field will print indented from the rest of the fields
      public ComplexField<ExampleSubMap> FourthField = new ComplexField<ExampleSubMap>("SubSection", ExampleSubMap.class); //bytes 20 - 35 (16 bytes total)
      
      //fields with dynamic sizes can also be constructred, as shown here. In this example, let's assume FirstField.getValueAsInt() = 50
      public BufferField VariableLengthField = new BufferField("Variable Length Field", FirstField.getValueAsInt()); //bytes 36 - 85 (50 bytes total)
      public ReservedField  Reserved1 = new Reserved(34); //bytes 86 - 99
      
      //Creates an array of fields that each contain the data in ExampleSubMap2
      //Each element of the array will be printed as its own complex field, with the name "Complex Array[0]", "Complex Array[1]", etc.
      public ComplexArrayField<ExampleSubMap2> ArrayField = new ComplexArrayField<ExampleSubMap2>("Complex Array", ExampleSubMap2.class, 12); //bytes 100 - 195 (96 bytes total. 12 elements at 8 bytes each)
 
      //definitions for the "sub" fields that are used by ComplexField and ComplexArrayField
      public class ExampleSubMap extends BufferMap
      {
          public ExampleSubMap(BufferMap parent)
          {
              super(parent);
          }
          
          public NumberField SubMapFirstField = new NumberField("Sub Map First Field", 2); //bytes 0 - 1 of this section
 
          //for this field, if the data at that section evaluates to either 0, 1, or 2, the corresponding enum name will also be printed
          public EnumNumberField<EnumExample> SubMapSecondField = new EnumNumberField<EnumExample>("Sub Map Second Field", 8, EnumExample.class); //bytes 2 - 9 of this section
          
          public StringField SubMapStringField = new StringField("Sub Map String Field", 6); //bytes 10 - 15 of this section
      }
 
      public class ExampleSubMap2 extends BufferMap
      {
          public ExampleSubMap2(BufferMap parent)
          {
              super(parent);
          }
 
          public String Field DataString = new StringField("Data String", 4, true); // bytes 0 - 3 of this section (the second parameter indicates to print the raw hex data for the string as well as the ASCII)
          public NumberField Data = new NumberField("Data", 4, Signedness.SIGNED); // bytes 4 - 7 (data is treated as a signed int instead of unsigned; i.e. 0xFFFFFFFF = -1 and not 4294967295)
      }
 
      public enum EnumExample
      {
           NAME_IF_FIELD_EVALUATES_TO_0,
           NAME_IF_FIELD_EVALUATES_TO_1,
           NAME_IF_FIELD_EVALUATES_TO_2
      }
 }
    Author:
    Kevin Thomson

      Nested Classes 
      Modifier and Type Class and Description
      protected class  BufferMap.AbstractArrayField<T extends BufferMap.AbstractField>
      The abstract class for dealing with an array of the same data type.
      class  BufferMap.AbstractField
      This is the base class for all Fields.
      static class  BufferMap.ArraySizeType
      enum for ComplexArrayField to indicate whether the size specified in the constructor is the number of elements in the array or the total size of the array in bytes
      class  BufferMap.BitField
      This class is for fields that are a single bit long
      class  BufferMap.BitsField
      This class is for fields that are less than a single byte long.
      class  BufferMap.BufferField
      This class is for fields that contain a large amount of data that does not need to be parsed By default, the toString() output only prints the number of bytes in the buffer.
      class  BufferMap.ComplexArrayField<E extends BufferMap>
      Class for representing a field that is an array of complex structures
      class  BufferMap.ComplexField<E extends BufferMap>
      This class is for specifying fields that themselves are complex structures that contain other fields
      class  BufferMap.EnumBitsField<T extends java.lang.Enum<?>>
      Similar to an EnumNumberField, but this works on fields that are only a few bits long
      class  BufferMap.EnumNumberField<T extends java.lang.Enum<?>>
      This class is for defining a field where each value has a specified meaning.
      class  BufferMap.IllegalValueInBufferFieldException
      Exception to indicate that, when building the list of AbstractField objects in the BufferMap, an error occurred because the structure defined is invalid in some way
      class  BufferMap.IllegalValueInStaticFieldException
      Exception to indicate that the value in a StaticNumberField or StaticStringFiled did not match the expected value
      static interface  BufferMap.IntegerEnum
      Interface used by Enums that do not represent a contiguous range of values.
      class  BufferMap.NullTerminatedStringField
      This class is for fields that are interpreted as ASCII strings that have an unknown length but will terminate in the NULL ('\0') character
      class  BufferMap.NumberArrayField
      Class for representing a field that is simply an array of numbers.
      class  BufferMap.NumberField
      This is used if the field is a simple integer value between 0 and 8 bytes long
      class  BufferMap.ReservedBitsField
      Class used to mark a series of bits that are reserved.
      class  BufferMap.ReservedField
      Class used to mark a series of bytes as reserved.
      class  BufferMap.StaticNumberField
      A NumberField where the value returned MUST equal the expectedValue specified.
      class  BufferMap.StaticStringField
      A StaticStringField where the value returned MUST equal the expectedValue specified or an IllegalValueInStaticFieldException will be thrown
      class  BufferMap.StringField
      This class is for fields that are interpreted as ASCII strings

        public BufferMap(java.lang.String name,
         byte[] data,
         Buffer.Endian endian,
         int startOffset)
        Basic constructor for BufferMap.
        Parameters:
        name - - the name of the map. Will be displayed at the top of toString()
        data - - the data to be parsed
        endian - - the endianness (BIG or LITTLE) of the data in the byte array
        startOffset - - offset into the buffer to begin parsing

      • BufferMap

        public BufferMap(BufferMap parent,
         java.lang.Object... additionalParameters)
        "SubClass Constructor"

        Constructor to use when to have an BufferMap that contains data that is a subset of a larger map. To access any of the additionalParameters specified in the constructor, call 

         Object getAdditionalParameter(int i)
        IMPORTANT NOTE: All subclasses that use this constructor must keep it in this exact format:

        public E(BufferMap parent, Object... additionalParams)

        Parameters:
        parent -
        additionalParameters -

    • Method Detail

      • getAdditionalParameter

        public java.lang.Object getAdditionalParameter(int i)
        Parameters:
        i - the additional parameter to be returned
        Returns:
        the specified additional parameter that was passed into to the SubClass Constructor. No bounds checking is done. It is necessary to go through this mechanism when passing in an additional parameter to the SubClass Constructor instead of simply creating a local variable inside the sub class and instantiating it inside that class constructor after the call to super(). This is because that local variable does not get instantiated until AFTER all of the AbstractField classes inside that class are constructed, and thus it would not be able to be used
        Throws:
        java.lang.ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if no additional parameters were specified in the constructor or an invalid index is specified

      • getParent

        public BufferMap getParent()
        Returns:
        the parent of this map, if applicable. Base maps have no parent

      • getCurrentOffset

        protected int getCurrentOffset()
        Returns:
        the byte offset that we are currently pointing at

      • getCurrentBitOffset

        protected int getCurrentBitOffset()
        Returns:
        the current bit offset. Will be 0 unless BitsFields are being processed

      • getCurrentSizeOfMap

        public int getCurrentSizeOfMap()
        Returns:
        total size in bytes being parsed by the map. Can be less than the size of the buffer itself

      • getMapName

        public java.lang.String getMapName()
        Returns:
        the name of the map that was specified in the constructor

      • getSizeOfRemainderOfBuffer

        public int getSizeOfRemainderOfBuffer()
        Returns:
        the amount of bytes that are remaining in the buffer, based on the current fields being parsed

        public java.lang.String toString()

      • enableDebug

        public static void enableDebug(boolean enable)
        Will enable debugging, which will print useful information about each field, including it's offset into the buffer and size.

        This is useful if you want to make sure you didn't make a mistake creating a map and marked a field with the wrong size, as this will throw off the offsets for every field following it

        Disabled by default

        Parameters:
        enable -

      • enableReservedFieldPrinting

        public static void enableReservedFieldPrinting(boolean enable)
        will enable printing of all reserved fields in the buffer map off by default. enabling debug will also enable this feature
        Parameters:
        enable -
